) International seizure and forfeiture is an important and integral aspect of forfeiture program. The means by which we effect cooperation with other countries, the procedures we use to effect seizure and forfeiture, and the benefits of accomplishing these tasks will be discussed in-depth in this (

) Oftentimes major drug traffickers and other organized criminals hide the gained proceeds outside of their own country. Accordingly, if those assets States Policy to be seized and eventually forfeited, it will require cooperation and tion between the countries involved. (

) It is the policy and the practice of the United States government to aggres- sively pursue the seizure and forfeiture of assets that are moved to, or in, other countries. If successful, the result will be to achieve our primary of taking the profit out of crime. (

) For forfeiture laws to work effectively, the United States and its partners must work together to enforce both their domestic and their tional enforcement efforts. The United States can, and should, pursue the forfeiture of assets found abroad, as well as assist other countries whose assets are hidden in this country. (

) Our domestic forfeiture program has shown us that the forfeited wealth that results from our efforts has effectively enhanced both our own law of International efforts, as well as those of the other agencies who cooperated in our tions. At the same time, when the proceeds from our international are equitably shared with our international counterparts, interagency tion is enhanced and the resources needed to continue our efforts to crime are replenished. (

) The United States stands ready to both pursue the forfeiture of assets as well as cooperate with the forfeiture efforts of other nations who have traced ill-gotten gains into our country. Regardless of whether our efforts in asset sharing, international forfeiture cooperation between countries still helps us to achieve our primary objective of removing assets from and taking the profit out of crime. (
) Currently there are four basic means by which international cooperation initiated: International a. Bilateral Treaties b. Multinational Agreements c. Executive Agreements d. Letters Rogatory (

) All of these tools have helped to regularize international forfeiture and are discussed below. A fifth option exists, that is obtaining the of the defendant, and that too will be discussed in this section. (

) A Bilateral Treaty is an agreement between two countries that specifies the mutual forfeiture assistance that the countries will provide to each other. Treaties terms of the agreement are included in a document known as a Mutual Assistance Treaty (MLAT). The United States has ratified MLATs with many jurisdictions. A current list of MLAT countries can be located on the CI International Section.

) Bilateral Treaties, in simple terms, are laws that require cooperation two countries. All of the existing treaties contain provisions for providing records and for “freezing” and/or seizing assets. They have also helped to regularize the international forfeiture cooperation between treaty partners. (

) A Multilateral Treaty is identical in nature to the Bilateral Treaty, with the exception that more than two countries are involved. The same procedures Treaties followed and the same benefits are obtained. (

) Executive Agreements are also legal agreements between countries. they supplement an existing MLAT between the countries where additional terms are needed to provide a basis for forfeiture cooperation and/or asset sharing. (

) Letters Rogatory are more time consuming, but they are the more means of obtaining assistance from a foreign court. They remain available use in cases where the United States and the foreign jurisdiction are not parties to a forfeiture related Bilateral Treaty, Multilateral Treaty, or Agreement. (

As with any other seizure action, it is vitally important to determine both the benefits and the detriments of a potential seizure before it is effected. (
